column1:
I sing the earth, vast and unyielding,
Her roots spread deep beneath our feet,
She whispers in the winds, calls in the rivers,
Her breath is the rain, her voice the thunder.

The mountains bow to her will,
The oceans kiss her shores,
Every leaf and blade of grass sings her name,
For she is the mother, the giver of life.

I feel her pulse in the heart of every man,
In the dust that coats my hands,
I am but a part of her endless circle,
A single note in her eternal song.

O, Earth! I stand with you,
Unshackled, free,
For in your vast embrace,
I am made whole, I am born anew.

O strong hands that labor,
You who bend and lift beneath the sun’s harsh gaze,
Whose muscles sing the song of toil,
You are the backbone of this world,
The silent strength beneath its grandeur.

I see you, the maker of roads and walls,
The tiller of soil, the builder of cities,
Your sweat, your fire, your pulse–
All part of the endless work of creation.

You are the ones who rise early,
Whose eyes are bright with purpose,
Who know that every moment of effort
Brings us closer to the promise of the future.

In you, I see myself,
The dreamer, the thinker, the lover,
For in your labor, I find my own.

O the road! O the boundless horizon,
Stretching endless into the unknown!
I will walk it without hesitation,
My feet kissing the dust,
My heart beating with the rhythm of the earth.

I do not fear the twists and turns,
The storms that will come,
For in the journey lies the truth of life,
In the crossing of the distance,
The soul finds its measure.

Who is this I meet along the way?
The poet, the soldier, the lover,
We are all pilgrims in this vast expanse,
Each of us seeking something,
Each of us finding all.

I lift my eyes to the heavens,
To the sparkling tapestry of night,
Each star a whisper, each constellation a story,
I hear the song of the cosmos,
Its music ancient and eternal.

How small we are beneath this sky,
How fleeting our moments,
Yet how magnificent,
To stand in the presence of these burning lights,
To know that we are part of this great whole.

O, stars! Sing to me,
Your song of infinity,
For in your light,
I see the vastness of all that is,
And I am humbled,
I am free.

I am wild,
Not in the sense of chaos,
But in the fullness of my being,
In the untamed pulse of life,
That rushes through my veins like a river unbound.

I have no master but the wind,
No law but the heartbeat of the earth,
I am a creature of the wild spaces,
Of the hills and valleys where the hawk soars,
Where the wolf runs through the silent forest.

I feel it in the wind,
In the beat of my own heart,
I am both man and beast,
Unfettered, uncontained,
A wild thing, a free thing–
Alive in the world,
Alive in myself.

O sky, you endless blue,
Your expanse stretches beyond all measure,
I, a single soul, stand beneath you,
A speck, a flicker, yet part of your vastness.

I breathe you in, your air, your light,
I drink your endless wells of freedom,
You who hold the stars,
Who cradle the sun as it rises and sets.

What is my life, if not a moment within you?
What is my heart, but a beat carried on your wind?
I am both small and infinite,
For in your embrace, I too am free.

O river, you unending current,
You who carve through stone, through time,
You are the voice of the earth,
A song that never ceases,
A song that calls to me.

I hear your murmur in the night,
I see your shimmer beneath the moon,
Your waters carry me forward,
Not to a distant shore,
But into the depths of my own soul.

I stand at your edge,
And I too am swept away–
For in your flow,
I find my own direction.

I hear the footsteps of a thousand souls,
Each one a heartbeat,
Each one a cry for justice, for love,
We march together,
As one, toward the future.

Our hands are rough, our faces tired,
But our will is unbroken,
For we are the children of the earth,
And the earth will not forsake us.

O brothers and sisters,
We walk side by side,
Our voices a chorus,
Our steps a testament to all that we believe.

I am the poet,
The one who speaks the words unsaid,
Who hears the silence in the wind,
And translates it into song.

I walk with the dreamers, the lost, the wandering,
I am their voice,
I am the echo of their cries,
The breath of their hopes.

For I do not sing only for myself,
But for all who have no song,
For all who have no voice–
My words are the breath of humanity.

O heart, beating within me,
You are both the storm and the calm,
The fire that drives me forward,
The silence that grounds me.

I hear your pulse in the quiet hours,
I feel your rhythm in the rush of the day,
You are the pulse of the universe,
The very beat of life itself.

I will follow you, wherever you lead,
Through joy, through sorrow,
For in your song,
I find my own truth.

The dawn–like a whispered secret–breaks,
And scatters the hush of night.
A thread of light–so fragile, so still–
Is woven through the fading white.

The birds, they stir in timid grace,
Not yet to sing, but softly rest,
As though the morning's first embrace
Must gather courage to be blessed.

And I–alone in shadow's keep–
Am drawn to this serene divide–
Where waking calls and sleeping sleep
Meet in the space where time can hide.

For in that quiet–brief, untold–
The day begins, and I, withhold.

The garden lies in silence–still–
Its blossoms closed, its branches bare,
And though the earth is cold and chill,
A secret stirs within the air.

The snow, it falls–so soft, so deep,
A blanket stitched from sky to ground,
Yet underneath–while all seems asleep–
A quiet pulse, a hidden sound.

For time, in winter, does not cease,
But holds its breath, and waits in peace–
A promise swells in nature’s breast,
That spring will come, and bring its rest.

The light–the fleeting kind we chase–
Dances upon the morning's face,
Yet when we seek its golden trace,
It slips away–a quiet grace.

I stood upon the edge of thought,
Where time and I are seldom caught,
And wondered if we had forgot–
What once was clear, what once was sought.

For in the shade of evening’s wings,
We lose the weight of simple things,
And ponder if the heart still sings
The song it heard before it clings.

The sparrow sings–though none can hear,
Her song–a secret to the ear,
Yet in the silence–pure and near,
She whispers truths the heart holds dear.

She knows no stage, nor crowd, nor light,
Her melody is soft as night,
Yet in her breast–a flicker bright–
That tells of joy, in quiet flight.

And I–who listen, though unseen–
Find solace in the spaces between,
For sometimes what is heard, unseen,
Is louder than the world has been.

A thought–like wind–has touched my mind,
It stirs the leaves, but leaves no trace–
It flutters soft, and then it’s gone–
A whisper lost without a face.

I reach for it–but cannot hold,
It slips between my grasping hand–
And like a dream, so faint, so cold,
It vanishes upon the land.

Yet in its wake–a gentle stir,
A sense of something left behind–
A ripple on the silver air,
A question in the quiet mind.

The room is still, the light is low,
And shadows stretch where none may go–
A quiet weight upon the air,
As though the world forgot its care.

The clock, it ticks–a soft refrain,
A song of time that knows no gain–
Yet in this pause, this sacred hush,
I feel the pulse of life’s own rush.

For in the silence, all things meet,
The past, the present–still, complete–
And though the world may spin away,
Here, in this room, I’ll always stay.

The garden breathes in quiet sighs,
Its petals closed beneath the skies,
And though the world may race on by,
It knows no hurry, knows no cry.

Each bloom unfolds in secret grace,
A quiet joy in nature’s place,
And I–who walk amidst the green–
Am stirred by what is seldom seen.

For life is whispered in the leaves,
In quiet places, where it grieves–
And in the silence, I can feel
The world’s soft pulse, so calm, so real.

A word once spoken–fades away,
But echoes still within the day,
And though the sound is lost to time,
Its ripples stretch beyond the rhyme.

I’ve asked for answers, sought the truth,
But all I found was fleeting youth,
A moment’s glance, a shadow’s grace–
And silence filled the hollow space.

Yet in that silence–still and deep,
I find a peace that gently creeps,
For sometimes in the quiet place,
The heart discovers endless grace.

The stars above, so cold, so bright,
They pierce the dark, they fill the night,
Yet in their glow, so vast, so far,
I wonder if they know who we are.

We look to them, with hearts that yearn,
For answers we may never learn,
And though their light is calm and true,
They speak no word, they never knew.

Still, we gaze up, through endless skies,
Seeking the truth behind their eyes,
And in that silence, we believe–
That stars are answers we receive.

I stood upon the edge of dreams,
Where shadows whispered, soft as streams,
And in the dark, a secret lay–
A glimpse of light, a fleeting ray.

The world behind me seemed to fall,
A distant echo, faint and small,
And in the hush, I dared to see
The truth that hides so quietly.

But as I reached, the light withdrew,
A flash of hope that I once knew,
And I–left standing, still and cold–
Was left to wonder, shy and bold.

For dreams are shadows in the night,
A dance of dark, a dance of light–
And though I grasp, I never hold
The fleeting truth, so soft, so bold.

Beneath the moon, so pale and cold,
I wander where the night unfolds,
And in my heart, a fire still burns–
A flame that flickers, yet it yearns.

For once, it blazed in fervent might,
A passion that consumed the night,
But now, it wanes, and yet remains–
A haunting echo of past pains.

Oh, love! Thou art a cruel thief,
That steals the joy, then leaves the grief.
Thy promises, like fleeting rain,
Now vanish with the morning's pain.

Yet still, I chase thee–hopeless, wild,
As though I were a broken child,
For even in this dark despair,
I seek the love that once was fair.

But time, it mocks, and winds it blows,
And love–once tender–now it goes.
So here, I stand, a soul undone,
For thee, my love, my race is run.

Beneath the moon’s unfeeling glow,
I wander where the cold winds blow,
And in my chest–my heart, so frail–
It beats for love, but finds no trail.

I’ve sought it once, I’ve sought it twice,
And yet, it flees–like rolling dice.
A fleeting glance, a distant touch–
But none can give me love’s true clutch.

Oh, what is life if love be lost?
A bitter cup, a heavy cost.
I’ve drunk from sorrow’s cruel cup,
Yet still I yearn, and cannot stop.

The world may turn, the years may pass,
But love–like shadows–does not last.
And still, I chase it through the night,
A soul in search of endless light.

For in this world of fleeting grace,
What else is left but love’s embrace?
Yet though it slips beyond my sight,
I’ll chase it still, through endless night.

I walk alone, the road ahead,
With weary feet and heart of lead,
For every step I take, I find
Another shadow left behind.

The world is bright, yet dimmed for me,
A distant shore, a restless sea–
The winds that call, the waves that roar,
Are lost to me forevermore.

I loved, I hoped, I dared to dream,
But love, like night, has lost its gleam–
And in my chest, a hollow space,
Where once there bloomed a lover’s grace.

Yet still I walk, though all is gone,
A soul that lingers, still undone–
For though the past may break and fall,
I’ll rise again, and face it all.

And in the distance, faint and far,
I see the glow of some bright star–
Perhaps a dream, perhaps a lie,
But still I walk, and still I try.

I heard the song the night began,
A melody of love's cruel plan,
Its notes were soft, yet sharp as steel,
And filled the heart with endless zeal.

Yet none could hear, save I alone,
For love’s sweet voice is always thrown
Into the dark, where none may see–
A light that dies in mystery.

I sought it high, I sought it low,
Through fields of fire, through winds that blow,
But love, like shadows, slipped away,
A fleeting dream, a bright decay.

Oh, love! Why do you hide so well,
A secret locked, a silent spell?
You lead me on, then disappear–
A song I chase, yet never hear.

But still I call, though none reply,
And walk beneath the weeping sky.
For in my heart, a fire burns–
A love that stirs, yet never returns.

The fire within me burns too bright,
A flame that flickers through the night,
Its heat–its hunger–claims my soul,
A raging force I can’t control.

I loved, I burned, I gave it all,
But like the wind, it ceased to call–
And in the ashes, I remain,
A heart undone by love’s cruel chain.

Oh, love–thy power is fierce, untamed,
A force that neither falls nor fades,
But leaves behind a trace of pain,
A mark upon the heart that stays.

And yet, I stand–against the storm,
With heart aflame and spirit warm,
For though the fire may sear and burn,
I’ll rise again, and dare return.

The world may mock, the world may sigh,
But in my heart, I’ll never die–
For in the flames, we rise and yield,
We conquer all, and never kneel.

The storm is wild, the skies are torn,
And in my heart, a tempest born–
A love that crashes, fierce, untamed,
And leaves me both undone and named.

I sought the shore, I chased the light,
But love, like waves, eludes my sight.
It calls to me with whispered cries,
A promise in the stormy skies.

Yet every kiss, like salt on skin,
Is bitter-sweet, and draws me in.
The winds they howl, the seas they rage,
And still, I stand upon the stage.

For though the storm may break and fall,
I seek the love that conquers all–
The flame that burns through darkest night,
The heart that dares to take the fight.

And when the winds have gone to rest,
I'll find my peace, though love's a jest.
For in the storm, I am reborn,
A soul that rises, never torn.

The night is deep, the stars are bright,
But none can pierce the endless night,
For in my soul–there burns a flame,
A love that none can ever tame.

It whispers soft, yet calls so loud,
A voice that lifts me from the crowd,
And though I chase the fleeting light,
It fades before the morning’s sight.

Oh, love! Thou art a shadow’s dance–
A fleeting glance, a stolen chance.
Yet still, I chase with heart untamed,
As though I seek what can't be named.

The winds may howl, the seas may roar,
But still I long for something more–
A dream that lies beyond the dawn,
Where love is free and life goes on.

But as the morning breaks the spell,
I stand alone, with naught to tell.
For love, like shadows, slips away–
And leaves me longing for the day.

I walk the world with shattered chains,
A heart that beats in restless strains.
No throne shall bind my spirit’s flight,
No lover's kiss shall quell the night.

For in my veins–wild fire stirs,
A rebel soul that never errs.
I’ve loved, I’ve lost, I’ve burned and bled,
But still I rise, though others dread.

The road is dark, the skies are torn,
But from the storm, my heart is born.
The world may mock, the heavens scorn,
Yet I remain–unbowed, untorn.

Oh love, thou art a cruel jest,
A fleeting fire, a fleeting quest–
But I, untamed, shall never rest,
For in my soul, the fight is blessed.

Let tempests roar and winds collide,
I’ll face the world with none to guide.
For though I fall, I rise again,
A rebel heart–unchained by men.

Upon the shore, I stand alone,
Where waves do crash, where winds have blown,
And in the distance–far, untold–
The horizon fades to shades of gold.

I’ve known the weight of countless years,
Of love, of loss, and silent tears.
The world, it spins–a ceaseless wheel–
Yet none shall know the wounds I feel.

For in my heart, a tempest stirs,
A longing fierce that never blurs.
The stars, they fade, the night is long,
Yet still, I chase the distant song.

Oh, fleeting joy, oh, fleeting grace–
Why must you vanish, leave no trace?
Yet still I chase, though worn and gray–
For in the chase, I’ll find my way.

And though the end may come too soon,
I'll face it with the rising moon.
For what is life but fleeting fire,
A spark, a flame–then we expire.

Upon the cliffs, where winds do rage,
I stand alone–upon the stage
Of life and death, of love and fear,
With none but echoes drawing near.

For love, once bright, now lies in chains,
Its tender whispers turned to pains,
And in my soul, I feel the fight–
A heart reborn from endless night.

Oh, cruel and fickle Fate, I cry!
What is it that compels the sky
To rain on those who dare to dream,
And tear apart the brightest gleam?

But I shall rise–though none may see–
A rebel heart, wild, fierce, and free.
For love, though lost, shall not be tame–
I’ll scorch the world and stake my claim.

Though darkness whispers in my ear,
I shall not bow, I shall not fear.
Let Fate be harsh, let time be cruel–
I’ll fight, and never be the fool.

When you, dear heart, are far from me in sleep,
I count the hours as if the stars would fall.
In absence deep, my soul does sense the steep
Of longing’s height, which none can e’er forestall.

For though thy form may drift away from view,
My love doth anchor firm, unshaken still.
No passing day shall ever make it rue,
No fleeting hour, my love, shall cease to thrill.

And when the cruel hand of Time doth take
Its toll on all things fair, thy name shall burn
Like fires that in the night eternal wake,
To guide me ‘cross the dark, when I return.

So death shall not destroy our sacred bond,
For love, true love, shall carry on–beyond.

The rose that bloomed with all its fragrant might
Shall wither swift, and yield to winter’s chill.
What once did shine with color pure and bright,
Now fades, as shadows darken over hill.

Yet do not mourn the fading of the bloom,
For in its fall, it teaches what is true–
That beauty lies not in the face of doom,
But in the grace with which it bids adieu.

And though thy face may pale with passing years,
Thy spirit, like the rose, shall find its way–
In love’s true light, it shall not know the tears
That age and time might bring with bitter sway.

For beauty, dear, lies not in what doth fade,
But in the love that in thy heart is laid.

O Time, thou art the thief who steals my breath,
And steals the years that once were bright and clear.
Thy cruel hand doth usher in my death,
Yet leaves behind the sorrow and the fear.

Why dost thou take so swift my golden prime?
Why must the hourglass empty so fast?
I yearn for youth, but know that this is Time–
That which we love, it cannot ever last.

Yet in thy hands, I find my humble grace,
For Time does shape and carve the human soul.
Without thy sway, how could we know our place,
Or seek to make our lives one worthy goal?

Thus, Time, though harsh, is also sweet to me,
For thou dost teach me how to truly be.

The moon doth sail across the midnight sky,
A silver ship that cuts the blackened sea.
She casts her light where darkest shadows lie,
And whispers peace to all who wander free.

Her pale, soft glow doth kiss the earth below,
As lovers’ sighs are caught upon the breeze.
She knows the hearts of men, and helps them know
The quiet balm that brings their troubled ease.

Yet even she must set beyond the wave,
Her reign, like all, must one day meet its end.
No force, not even stars, can light the grave,
And all things–great and small–must break or bend.

But still the moon, she rises–night by night–
And keeps alive the hope of endless light.

When first I saw thee, eyes did meet and burn,
A spark ignited in my very soul.
I longed to touch, to feel, and to return
To thee, whose heart could make my spirit whole.

Thy gaze doth hold me fast, thy voice doth bind,
A prison, sweet, where I would choose to stay.
For in thy love, my heart doth freely find
Its home, its peace, its purpose–and its way.

Yet still I yearn, though love is pure and true,
For passion’s fire is ever fierce and wild.
And in thy arms, I seek to be made new,
A child of love, who knows no longer mild.

Thus, though my heart is thine–forevermore,
I yearn for thee, and love thee all the more.

The world doth weep and tremble in its grief,
As death doth steal away the ones we hold.
Yet in that sorrow lies a strange relief,
A wisdom found in stories yet untold.

For loss doth teach us what we cannot see,
The fleeting nature of this life we live.
It speaks of love, and how we long to be
True to the hearts we have, and yet forgive.

No pain shall last forever in the soul,
For after night, the sun will rise again.
And though we mourn, it makes our spirit whole,
To know that love and hope do yet remain.

So let not sorrow blind thee to the light,
For after grief, there comes the morning bright.

O fleeting youth! Thou art so swift to go,
Like winds that blow across the barren hill.
In thy sweet bloom, the world doth overflow,
Yet soon thy beauty, too, will bend and chill.

I see thee, now, a blossom in thy prime,
Thy eyes alight with wonder and with joy.
But know, dear heart, that soon will come the time
When Time itself shall thy bright light destroy.

Yet still I love thee, though thy bloom shall fall,
For in thy heart, a flame doth ever burn.
And though thy face may fade, I love thee all,
And in thy light, I find my soul’s return.

Thus, though thou pass, thy memory shall stay,
A star that guides me through the darkest day.

The summer’s end doth touch me with a sigh,
As autumn’s hand turns leaves to shades of gold.
The warmth of sun, the brightness in the sky,
Now fades away, and nights grow sharp and cold.

Yet still I cherish every fleeting day,
For in the end, the sun will rise once more.
The winds may blow and clouds may cloud the way,
But seasons change–forever to restore.

And though this summer fades into the past,
Its memories are etched in me so deep.
I’ll carry them, as though they’d ever last,
And in their light, my heart shall wake from sleep.

Thus, though all things must change, my love will stay,
A summer’s warmth to guide me through the gray.

The night doth whisper secrets in the dark,
A quiet song, unheard by waking ears.
Yet in the silence, there is such a spark,
A mystery that calms and quiets fears.

The stars, like jewels scattered far and wide,
Do twinkle softly in their solemn flight.
And though the world may rest with none beside,
The night does cradle all in peaceful light.

No voice is heard, no footstep stirs the air,
But in the stillness, hearts begin to heal.
For though the night is dark, there is no care–
Its calm, a balm, that time itself can steal.

O Silent Night, thy grace will never cease,
For in thy arms, the weary find their peace.

The time has come to say our last goodbye,
To part, though love doth bid us still to stay.
I see the tears that glisten in thine eye,
And yet I know, I must not turn away.

For love, though sweet, doth wear a cruel face,
And Fate, though kind, doth lead us to the end.
But in thy heart, I leave no bitter trace,
For love’s true power will never bend.

And though our paths may lead us far apart,
The bond we share shall never fade or die.
For love resides within the faithful heart,
And in its light, no distance can belie.

So let us part, but know this truth, my dear–
That love, though gone, is ever near.

In gardens where the roses cease to bloom,
And lilies weep beneath the silent sky,
There grows a flower that glows within the gloom,
Its fragrance laced with sweet and bitter sigh.

This blossom, bathed in twilight's dying fire,
Is born of love, but fed by shame and pain.
It blooms not to be loved, but to inspire
The yearning hearts that seek but can't obtain.

Yet still, we chase it–blind to what it costs,
As moths do flutter toward a dying flame.
We seek the beauty in the thing that’s lost,
And call it love–though never quite the same.

So in the garden of our deepest yearn,
We find that longing’s truth–when we return.

The mirror speaks of what it does not know,
A silent witness to our vain disguise.
It shows the face–yet never dares to show
The soul beneath, the mask, the hidden lies.

It tells of beauty, fleeting, soft as light,
But leaves behind the shadows of despair.
For in its gaze, we seek both wrong and right,
And find in truth, no truth that can compare.

Yet still, we smile and fix our gaze upon
The glass that holds the image of our mind,
Believing what we see is never gone,
And what we seek, we know we’ll never find.

The mirror knows not love, nor love’s regret,
But fools we are to call it our duet.

A voice, a song, a melody so sweet,
It calls to me through night’s eternal thrall.
I hear it in the winds, upon the street,
It beckons–no one dares to turn or fall.

For though its beauty promises release,
The melody hides treachery and pain.
It wraps the heart in chains, then calls for peace–
The siren’s voice–so laced with soft disdain.

How many hearts have drowned within its grasp,
Believing that its call was meant for them?
How many dreams, once bright, now turn to ash,
Consumed by love’s sweet, treacherous diadem?

Yet still, I listen–drawn to her deceit,
For in her song, I find my heart complete.

Beauty, thy price is not in gold or gem,
But in the soul that seeks thee, blind and lost.
What weight of hearts, what pangs of silent hymn,
Are borne by those who find thee–at what cost?

The world admires thee, but none can possess
The truth that lies behind thy fleeting face.
For though thou art a charm, a soft caress,
Thy charm conceals a bitter, hollow grace.

Yet still we seek thee, craving, day by day,
Not for thy warmth, but for thy sweet despair.
For in thy fleeting form, we fade away,
And in thy shadows, find a solace rare.

O Beauty! Thou art love, and yet thou’re cold–
A fleeting dream, a promise never told.

The rose, it blooms beneath the evening sky,
Its petals soft, its fragrance laced with sin.
Yet ‘neath its bloom, the thorns will tear and cry,
A love so sweet, but marked by what’s within.

For every rose that catches heart’s desire,
The thorns will mark it with a bitter scar.
And though it burns with passion’s fierce fire,
Its flame will leave a wound, a wound afar.

But still we seek the rose, despite the pain,
As if the thorns are part of love’s sweet kiss.
We call it passion–sorrow’s tender reign,
And never see the cost of love’s false bliss.

O rose, thy beauty calls us to thy doom,
And in thy scent, we find our certain tomb.

In gardens grown from whispered, stolen breath,
Where roses bloom of false and poisoned hue,
The lies we tell to save us from our death
Take root, and flower–bright, but never true.

The soil is rich with secrets we have sown,
And watered with the tears of those we trust.
Yet though these flowers bloom, they die alone,
For in the end, all lies return to dust.

Still, in this garden, we continue to play,
Tending the weeds and plucking false delight.
We walk among the blooms, though we must pay,
For in the lies, we bury all our might.

So let the garden die, let lies be done,
For truth alone shall bloom beneath the sun.

Thy grace was like a song upon the air,
A melody that charmed the soul to weep.
But in thy fall, I see a shadow there,
A beauty lost, a secret buried deep.

For thou, O fairest one, didst rise so high,
A goddess born from earth’s own sweetest clay.
Yet in thy flight, thou didst forget the sky,
And fell to earth–alone, in dark decay.

The heavens weep to see thee on the ground,
And angels mourn thy splendor’s fading hue.
But in thy fall, thy truth is fully found,
For even gods, in time, must pass from view.

Yet in thy ruin, still thou art divine,
A fall so great, that even stars decline.

The portrait hangs, a ghost of what once was,
A face, a smile, frozen in time’s embrace.
Yet none can tell what love or loss it caused,
Nor see the longing that this smile did chase.

For in the paint, there lies no beating heart,
No soul, no depth, no promise of the true.
Yet still, we stand before it, torn apart,
And dream of what we cannot ever do.

The artist’s hand did capture all our pain,
A frozen truth that time cannot erase.
And though the image seems so pure, so plain,
It hides the lies that none can e’er replace.

So let the portrait fade into the dark–
For love, true love, doth leave no lasting mark.

Thou art a temptress, veiled in softest grace,
A smile that wounds, a touch that bruises deep.
Thy lips, so sweet, conceal a bitter place,
And in thy arms, the soul is born to weep.

For in thy gaze, a fire–yet it’s cold,
A fire that burns, yet leaves the heart in chains.
Thy beauty’s warmth, it draws the heart to fold,
And yet the love it promises is vain.

Still, we adore thee, blind to what we feel,
For in thy art, we lose ourselves so sweet.
The lies we take from thee, we make them real,
And in thy wake, we find no place to meet.

Thy love’s a poison, yet we drink so fast–
For beauty hides the truth that cannot last.

Time, thou art but a dance, a fleeting waltz,
A pirouette that leaves no trace behind.
Yet still we follow, though our hearts revolt,
For in thy rhythm, we are lost–blind, blind.

Each step we take, each turn, each fleeting glance,
Is but a moment passing with a sigh.
Yet still we dance, as if we had the chance
To make thee stop, to make thee change–deny.

But Time, O Time, thou art both cruel and kind,
For in thy dance, we find no final place.
The world may fall, yet still we are entwined–
We’re part of thee, and lost within thy grace.

So let the music play, let it never cease–
For in thy steps, we seek our only peace.

O quiet heart, why dost thou weep
In silence, when the night is deep?
For though the stars their vigil keep,
No solace comes, no peace to sleep.

The moon, so pale, casts shadows cold,
Yet in my breast there stirs the old
Desire for love, for one who may
Not come, but leaves the soul astray.

The lilies bend their heads in prayer,
Their fragrance soft upon the air;
But still, my heart, it cannot rest,
For yearning fills the empty chest.

O fleeting days, why must you fly,
Like winds that pass the open sky?
In all this world, I seek but this–
A fleeting touch, a fleeting kiss.

Yet though my prayers may never be,
And hopes may fade as dawn turns free,
I trust that love, though far from sight,
Will bring its peace at last–tonight.

What song is this that stirs the air,
A song of sorrow, soft and rare?
It whispers low, it fades, it dies–
A dream lost under darker skies.

I sang it once, in days of light,
A tune so sweet, so pure, so bright.
But time has passed, and all I hear
Are echoes faint, and traces clear.

O fleeting joy, O fleeting song,
Why did you stay so brief, so long?
My heart, though broken, still recalls
The melody behind these walls.

Yet silence falls where music grew,
And in the dark, I see no hue.
The flowers bloom, the birds still sing,
But none will answer what I bring.

A song once bright, now lost, unknown,
As leaves upon the winds are blown.
Yet still I sing, though none may hear,
For in my soul, the song is near.

A rose once bright, now pale and torn,
Its petals fall, its thorns adorn,
A symbol of what once was fair,
Now lost to time, to cold, to air.

I held it close, this flower dear,
Its fragrance sweet, its beauty clear,
But fleeting as the morning dew,
It withered slowly, pale and blue.

O love, so sweet, so fleeting bright,
Why dost thou vanish in the night?
Like roses, all things bloom and fade,
And leave behind a soft cascade.

Yet in the soil where roses lie,
New blooms will spring, though hearts may sigh,
And though the past may fade away,
Its memory lingers, soft as day.

So let the rose now rest in peace,
Its beauty gone, its pain released,
For though the blooms may turn to dust,
The love we gave is all we trust.

O heart, so weary, faint, and tired,
That once with love and hope aspired,
Now bound by sorrow, wrapped in night,
A shadow drifting out of sight.

The days pass slow, the nights are long,
And in the quiet, I grow strong–
Not from the joy that once was near,
But from the silence, born of fear.

Yet in my soul, a longing stirs,
A yearning soft as winter’s fur,
For what I knew and lost so deep,
For love I held and cannot keep.

The stars, they gleam so far above,
They whisper tales of hidden love–
But still, I wait, with quiet grace,
For time to heal this hollow space.

O heart, though bound by aching chains,
Your love shall rise through all your pains,
For though the world may turn away,
Your longing finds the light of day.

I stand upon the shore alone,
The tide it rolls, the winds have blown,
And in the distance, far from sight,
The land of dreams glows soft with light.

O fleeting hope, so far away,
That calls to me at close of day,
Your promise bright, yet fading fast,
A distant vision that cannot last.

The waves, they rise, then fall again,
And with them, rise my heart’s own pain,
For though the shore is near to see,
Its touch remains a mystery.

Yet still I long to reach that place,
Where love and peace do interlace,
And though the journey seems so far,
I keep my gaze upon the star.

For though the tide may pull me back,
And shadows darken all I lack,
I know that someday, soft and true,
That distant shore will come to view.

Beneath the boughs where shadows creep,
A garden lies, in quiet sleep,
Its flowers pale, its grasses low,
Where none may see, where none may know.

The roses bow their heads in grief,
The ivy winds its quiet leaf,
And in the stillness, soft and deep,
The heart’s own secrets gently weep.

I tend the soil, I wait in vain,
For love to grow, to ease my pain,
But time, it passes, slow and true,
And all I plant lies wet with dew.

O silent garden, still and bare,
Your beauty’s lost, your fragrance rare.
Yet in your soil, a promise lies,
For every seed that falls shall rise.

So though the years may leave me cold,
And love may fade, or grow too bold,
I trust that in this silent place,
A bloom shall rise, and know its grace.

The dawn is breaking, soft and slow,
With rose-lit skies and waters' glow,
Yet in my heart, a shadow lies,
A whispered sorrow, unseen eyes.

The birds take flight, the flowers bloom,
The air is sweet with spring’s perfume,
But in the quiet of my soul,
A longing stirs, beyond control.

O fleeting days, so swift they pass,
Like moments in a looking glass–
The joy they bring, the pain they leave,
Are all that I can taste or grieve.

Yet in the veil of dawn’s first light,
There lies a peace, a love so bright,
Though it may fade, though it may fall,
It whispers softly to my soul.

So let me walk through days of gray,
With hope as light to guide my way,
For though the dawn may fade to night,
Its promise lingers, soft and bright.

I watch the stars that softly burn,
Their silver fires turn and turn,
And in their glow, I find no rest,
No peace to settle in my chest.

The moon, a pale and fleeting queen,
Looks down upon the world unseen,
And in her gaze, so cold, so still,
There stirs a grief that time can't heal.

I walk the path where shadows fall,
Where echoes linger, faint and small,
And though the world is bright and fair,
I carry sorrow everywhere.

O silent watcher, lost in space,
What is this ache I cannot trace?
A longing deep, a wish unspoken,
A heart that feels forever broken.

Yet still, I wait, as night unfolds,
For in its dark, some truth beholds–
A quiet grace, a tender touch,
That soothes the soul, yet costs so much.

When morning breaks with softest light,
And shadows flee from breaking night,
I wake and sigh, for what I’ve known
Is lost, as day has swiftly flown.

The world is fair with skies so blue,
The flowers bright with morning’s dew,
But in my heart, a quiet ache,
A longing for what I cannot take.

O fleeting dream, so swiftly gone,
Why must you vanish with the dawn?
My soul, it calls to something more,
Yet finds no answer on the shore.

The roses bloom, the birds take flight,
And in my soul, there stirs a night
Of quiet thoughts I cannot quell,
Of loves and dreams I cannot tell.

So while the world around me wakes,
And morning’s golden promise breaks,
I hold my heart and pray for peace,
And hope the restless ache will cease.

I walked within my garden’s shade,
Where roses bloomed and ivy laid,
A secret place, a silent space,
Where time itself did leave no trace.

The lilies, white as morning's light,
Did whisper softly, pure, and bright,
And all the flowers in their bloom
Seemed filled with joy to banish gloom.

Yet in the midst, my heart did weep,
For love, once given, now did sleep,
And though the petals sweetly fell,
A distant sorrow none could quell.

Oh, gentle wind that stirs the leaves,
Why must my soul so long and grieve?
For what is love but fleeting air,
A thing to find, but not to spare?

So here I stand, alone, yet blessed,
My garden holds me, though oppressed,
For in its soil, though grief may grow,
There blooms a seed of hope below.

In chambers cold, where shadows creep,
And ancient walls in silence weep,
A figure stirs, a faint disguise,
A phantom with forgotten eyes.

The clock does tick, yet stands no more,
For time is lost on death’s dark shore.
Each second drips like blood from stone,
Each breath a sigh, a mournful moan.

The veil of night begins to tear,
Revealing depths of dark despair,
Where all that lives and once had grace
Is now erased from time and place.

I hear it call–a whispered name,
A voice that burns with ghostly flame,
Yet when I turn, there's none to see,
But the hollow air that clings to me.

Oh, fleeting world of sorrow’s spin,
What cold, grim fates await within?
The phantom’s veil, the mist, the dream–
All lost within this darkened scheme.

Upon the hill, where shadows stand,
A grave awaits with cold, dark hand,
And in its depths, a secret lies,
Veiled from the touch of earthly eyes.

The winds do howl, the stars do fade,
As though the night itself is made
Of sorrow’s thread, of death’s own breath,
A chilling hymn of certain death.

I stand before the tombstone worn,
Its name erased, its soul forlorn,
And wonder who, or what, was laid
In that dark earth, so cold, betrayed.

The silence speaks–a haunting cry,
Of lives forgotten, doomed to die.
Yet in this tomb, this hollowed space,
I sense a shadow’s fleeting grace.

For in the dark, I hear a plea,
A whispered voice that calls to me,
But who it is, I cannot tell,
For it is lost within the spell.

The tomb, it calls, its door ajar,
A glimpse of something–strange, bizarre.
Yet still I stand, and none may see
The secret tomb that waits for me.

Beneath the stars, so pale and dim,
I walk the path, so dark, so grim,
Where silence reigns, and shadows twist,
And all the world seems lost in mist.

The hollowed heart within my chest
Beats slow, as if it knows no rest.
Its rhythm calls a mournful tune,
A song that rises with the moon.

What wicked fate did bind my soul
To tread this earth with no control?
For every step, a deeper scar,
A soul undone, a wounded star.

The winds, they whisper tales of old,
Of death and dreams that once were bold.
Yet here I stand, alone, in pain,
Bound to this cursed, endless strain.

And when the dawn begins to creep,
I hear the whispers in my sleep,
A cry that echoes from the deep–
The curse of hearts that never sleep.

In twilight’s grasp, I stand alone,
Where shadows stretch and winds have grown,
The trees are bent in mournful sighs,
And heaven weeps with distant cries.

The echo calls, a hollow sound,
That rises from the hollow ground,
A voice that whispers, faint and clear,
Yet speaks of sorrow, pain, and fear.

What ghostly hand has drawn the line
That binds my soul to death’s design?
For every step I take in night,
I lose a piece of fading light.

The world is wrapped in endless gray,
As though the stars have turned away,
And in the stillness, I must roam,
To seek what’s lost, to find no home.

The echo calls with voices old,
A tale of woe, of love grown cold.
I search for it, but none may see
The endless void that calls to me.

In shadows deep, where none may tread,
The air grows cold, the spirits dead,
A cry resounds, both sharp and clear,
A voice that trembles, filled with fear.

I wander 'neath the weeping sky,
Where moonlight fades, where shadows die,
And in the gloom, I hear it call–
A wretched plea, a twisted thrall.

Oh cursed soul, once free, once bright,
Now bound to wander endless night.
What cruel fate has torn apart
The fragile threads that filled the heart?

The hollow wind it stirs the dust,
A tomb of sorrow, heart of rust,
And from the dark, I hear the sound
Of souls that tremble in the ground.

Forsaken, lost, they cry and wail,
For all they love has gone and failed.
And in their grief, they roam the skies,
A soulless echo, never wise.

Beneath the moon’s pale, flickering light,
I stand beside the grave tonight.
The winds do howl, the branches bend,
And whisper softly of my end.

I weep for him who lies below,
For love once bright, now laid in snow.
The earth, it calls with icy breath,
To claim the soul that’s tied to death.

O cruel, unyielding hand of Fate,
That sealed his doom, that sealed my state–
For in the dark, I cannot flee
The shadow that now follows me.

His voice, once warm, now calls no more,
His touch, once soft, now gone from shore.
Yet in the silence, I still wait,
For him to rise, to lift my fate.

The moon, it fades, the stars grow dim,
As if they mourn for love so grim.
Yet still I stand, beside his grave,
A widow’s heart, too lost to save.

At midnight's stroke, the silence falls,
A deeper hush in darkened halls,
Where whispers lost in shadows creep,
And souls of sorrow wake from sleep.

The clock, it ticks with hollow sound,
Its echo haunting all around,
Each chime a toll for what is gone,
For dreams that fade at early dawn.

Beneath the veil of misty skies,
A fleeting shadow stirs and flies,
Its form a blur, its face unknown,
A wraith that haunts this world alone.

I seek no solace, no reprieve,
In this still hour, I grieve, I grieve;
For every breath, a fleeting sigh,
That fades and vanishes, to die.

The hour wanes, the dark persists,
And all I hear are empty fists,
That beat upon the doors of time–
A rhythm lost, a twisted rhyme.

In midnight's grasp, I wander deep,
Where shadows in the darkness sleep,
And silent tombs, with stone encased,
Hold secrets time cannot erase.

The stars above, they seem to cry,
A mournful song that fills the sky,
As if the heavens, cold and stark,
Are weeping for the souls in dark.

I stand before a crypt of old,
Its iron gate both grim and bold,
The whisper of a distant bell,
The toll of death, the ringing knell.

What sorrow lies beneath the earth?
What phantom waits to find rebirth?
I feel the chill, the touch of dread,
As spectral hands reach from the dead.

O’er me now, the winds do scream,
And shadows twist in death’s dark dream,
But still I stand, and none may see
The crypt's embrace that calls for me.

Beneath the moon's cold, dying light,
I hear a voice–a whispering fright,
It calls to me from deep within,
A mournful sound, a voice of sin.

The winds do howl with voices lost,
A haunting wail, a dreadful cost,
And in the distance, shadows play,
As if the night itself would sway.

The void before me, dark and deep,
Where endless secrets softly sleep,
I reach within, my hand does fall,
But only echoes greet my call.

What wretched soul, what twisted fate,
Lies hidden in that ghastly state?
I seek the truth, I seek release,
But find no solace, no peace.

The abyss it beckons, pulls me near,
With promises of hope and fear,
Yet in its depths, I know I’ll find
Only the silence of my mind.

Upon the hill where shadows creep,
And spectral winds through silence sweep,
I wander, lost in mournful thought,
Where dreams are frail and hope is naught.

The stars above, a distant gleam,
Are but the echoes of a dream,
And as the midnight bell does toll,
I feel the weight upon my soul.

In darkness deep, I seek to find
The secret that eludes my mind;
But in the depths of night's embrace,
I see a fleeting, mournful face.

A figure veiled in sorrow's guise,
With hollow, ancient, tear-filled eyes,
And as it fades within the mist,
I know that death cannot be missed.

Oh, cursed fate, so cruel, so near,
That fills the heart with deepest fear,
And leads me down this endless road,
Where grief and shadows intertwine and grow.

Syksy saapuu, tuuli tuivertaa,
Puut kuihtuvat ja lehdet hajoaa,
Vaan jossain kaukana soi vielä laulu,
Väreet sydämessä, kaipaus taulu.

Metsän hiljaisuus on syvä kuin yö,
Kivinen polku vie pois, kohti syvää syö,
Siellä on muistoja menneistä päivistä,
Hämärän alla, missä henki ei hymyile.

Tuntuu kuin maa ei kantaisi enää,
Kun sydänkin vajoaa, murtuu, ja tärisee
Vaan etsiessäni, vain varjoja näen
Pian lentävät linnut, eivät jää tänne.

O, rakkaus, mikä on tämän kaipauksen syy?
Onko se metsä vai tähdet yössä?
Jään tänne, vaikka et olekaan luonani,
Jätän sydämeni tuuleen, aavikon taivaan taa.

Tuuli kulkee metsän halki,
kantaa mukanansa syksyn kaihon,
sen laulussa soi muisto menneistä,
ja maa vastaa hiljaisuudellaan.

Olen kulkija, jalkani jättää
tien, joka ei vie minnekään,
mutta sydän palaa aina uudestaan
samaan paikkaan, samaan kaipaamiseen.

Puut kumartavat, pimeys syvenee,
ja tähdet katsovat minua kaukaa,
vähän väliä tuuli puhaltaa
ja kantaa unohduksia pois.

O, jospa voisin jäädä
tuon tuulen kanssa kulkemaan,
kulkea sinne, missä ei ole aikaa,
missä ei ole suruja, ei kipuja.

Mutta vain metsä, vain taivas
ja sydän, joka ei ole koskaan
löytänyt rauhaa, tuntee kaipauksen,
yksinäisyys on varjoni, jonka tunnen.

Yksinäinen tähti taivaalla syttyy,
sen valo on kuin kaukainen ikävä,
se loistaa hetken, heikkona, hiljaa,
ennen kuin yö sen peittää kokonaan.

Metsän alla, pimeässä polussa,
askeleet kaikuvat kuin muiston kuiskaus,
ja sydän, joka ei löydä rauhaa,
etsii paikkaa, jossa voi levätä.

Kaikki on hiljaa, vain tuuli kertoo
vanhoja tarinoita menneistä illoista,
ja missä ennen oli lämpöä,
on nyt vain kylmää, ja varjoja, jotka seuraavat.

O, rakkaus, miksi olet kaukana?
Miksi tähdetkin kätkevät kasvonsa?
Minä kuljen, vailla määränpäätä,
ja sydän kaipaa, vaikka ei tiedä mitä.

Mutta jokainen askel on kuin lupaus,
jokainen tuulen henkäys on kuin laulu,
joka vie minut kauemmas pois,
kohti paikkaa, missä kaikki on elämää.

Hämärä saapuu, hiljaa ja lempeästi,
varjot kasvavat, eikä enää mikään
mene ohi silmien,
kaikki on lähellä, mutta ei kosketettavissa.

Metsän syvä kuiskaus
kulkee kuin kaukainen muisto,
ja mieli vaeltaa sinne, missä ei ole aikaa,
vain tuuli ja unelmat, jotka ei koskaan täyty.

Oli hetki, jolloin maailma oli kirkas,
ja rakkaus oli lähempänä kuin taivas,
mutta nyt se on vain hämärä haave,
kaukana ja saavuttamattomissa.

Kulkija, joka etsii ja ei löydä,
askel kerrallaan, polut vievät pois
kaikesta, mihin oli uskottu,
vain yksinäisyys jää, eikä kukaan sitä näe.

Mutta taivaan silmät, tähdet,
ne katsovat alas, vailla sääliä,
ja minä jään tähän,
hiljaa, mutta en enää toivottomana.

Metsä on syvä, metsän hiljaisuus
kätkee kaikki tarinat ja salaisuudet,
sen puut, ne kumartuvat muistoille,
ja polut vievät sinne, minne ei voi palata.

Olen kulkija, sydän täynnä kaipuuta,
askel askeleelta, mutta ei määränpäätä,
metsä vain katsoo, kuuntelee,
ja minä jään sen varjoon, yksinäiseksi.

Oli aika, jolloin ääni oli kirkas,
rakkaus oli lähellä, kuin tuuli kesällä,
mutta nyt se on vain varjo,
joka seuraa mukanani joka askeleella.

Metsä ei kysy, ei vaadi, ei vastaa,
se on vain olemassa, syvällä, kaukana,
ja minä, kulkija, olen osa sitä,
yksinäinen, mutta ei enää eksynyt.

Metsä on hiljainen, mutta ei kylmä,
se ottaa vastaan kaikki, jotka eksyvät,
ja antaa heille rauhan, vaikka ei puhu,
se on paikka, jossa sydän voi levätä.

Järven pinta on kuin peili,
jossa heijastuu vain menneisyys,
siellä on kuvia, jotka eivät vanhene,
ja unelmia, jotka jäävät katveeseen.

Metsän taakse kätkeytyy ilta,
hiljaa ja syvältä, kuin varjo
jolle ei voi antaa nimeä,
vaan se kulkee mukana, äänettömänä.

Kivinen ranta, kylmä ja tumma,
murtuu jalkojen alla,
mutta sydän ei ehdi jäädä,
se seuraa jo tuulen mukana kauas.

Oli aika, jolloin silmät loistivat,
ja elämä oli täynnä lämpöä,
mutta nyt kaikki on vain kuvitelmaa,
kaukana, jonne ei voi palata.

O, järvi, joka kantaa katseeni,
mitä etsit, mitä kätket sisälläsi?
Vastaus ei koskaan tule,
mutta minä kysyn, aina uudelleen.

Metsä on syvä, ja tuuli on mykkä,
puut kumartavat, mutta eivät sano sanaakaan.
Jokainen oksa, joka taittuu,
on kuin huokaus, joka ei enää palaudu.

Kauas, niin kauas jäänyt on aika,
kun elämä oli kirkas kuin kevään sade,
mutta nyt on vain varjojen tanssi,
ja minä, kulkija, seuraan niitä hiljaisuudessa.

Metsän reuna on kaukana,
se on paikka, johon ei voi enää palata.
Kaikki on kuin unta, joka on jäänyt
puoleksi unohduksiin, puoleksi todellisuuteen.

Mutta täällä, metsän sydämessä,
tunnen sen, mikä ei koskaan katoa –
kaipauksen, joka ei ole hiljainen,
vaan se raivoaa, kaivaten jotain, jota ei ole.

Jään tänne, varjojen keskelle,
ei etsien, ei toivoen,
vaan antaen metsän hiljaisuuden
olla ainoa laulu, jonka kuulen.

Hämärä laskeutuu, hiljaa ja lempeästi,
metsä kuiskaa, tuuli kuljettaa unelmat,
ja minä seison, varjojen keskellä,
missä kaikki tuntuu olevan lähellä ja kaukana.

Taivaanrannassa tähdet syttyvät,
mutta ei ole enää valoa, joka loistaa,
vain niiden kylmä hehku, kaukainen,
kuten rakkaus, joka ei koskaan ollut minun.

Veden pinta on tyyni,
ei piirtäydy kuvia, ei ääniä,
vain tyhjä heijastus,
jossa kaikki sekoittuu, katoaa.

Oli aika, jolloin silmät loistivat,
ja maailma oli täynnä mahdollisuuksia,
mutta nyt kaikki on muisto,
joka katoaa, niinkuin aamukaste auringossa.

Kyllä, kuljen edelleen,
mutta en enää etsi, en enää toivo,
vaan annan hämärän tanssia ympärilläni,
ja annan sen viedä minut sinne, missä kaikki on hiljaista.

Metsän syvässä varjossa kuljen,
askeleeni hiljaa, kuin unessa,
puiden oksat, ne kuiskaavat nimeäni,
ja tuuli vie pois sanat, jotka jäävät sanomatta.

Yksi syksyn lehti putoaa,
sen värit haihtuvat, kuin muistot menneistä,
ja minä kuljen, en pysähdy,
vaikka jokainen askel tuo lähemmäs jotain kadonnutta.

Taivas on harmaa, pilvet kerääntyvät,
mutta sydämessäni ei ole sadetta,
vain kaipausta, joka ei sammu,
vaan jatkuu, vaikka vuoret kaatuvat.

Ja vaikka polku on kapea,
vaikka metsän syvyys tuntuu äärettömältä,
minä tiedän, että jossain, kaukana,
on paikka, jossa voi levätä, olla rauhassa.

Mutta ennen sitä, ennen löytämistä,
minä kuljen varjoissa, hiljaisuudessa,
koska vain siellä, puiden alla,
sydän voi ymmärtää, mitä se kaipaa.

O, kaukainen kotimaa, missä sydän jäi,
missä auringon viimeinen säde ei vielä sammu,
missä metsät kuiskii tarinoita menneistä,
